data.title: VS Code's Editor Window Does Not Show/Launch (Sometimes)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.14-insider & 0.10.11
- OS Version: Win10 Build 14279

Steps to Reproduce:
1. _Using and Closing VS Code (Standard or Insider)?_
2. (Re-)Launching VS Code

VS Code (Standard and Insider) will sometimes not show the IDE Window when launch. There are ~4x Code.exe or Code-Insider.exe process that show running in Task Manager. Beside rebooting, the only workaround I have found is deleting the files and directories in '...\AppData\Roaming\Code - Insiders\' or '...\AppData\Roaming\Code\' then relaunching it. 

What I have noticed is, CodeHelper.exe is never launched with the Code.exe or Code-Insider.exe when I am experiencing this issue.

I cannot find any debug/verbose log for VS Code or associated events in the Windows Event Log.

data.title: Intellisense for nodejs not working anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bit

I have a nodejs project that I was working on a few months ago and everything was great.
In the meantime, I had upgraded VScode to latest version.
Today I came back to the project and node intellisense is not working.
I made sure the tsd files were still there, and they are, in `\typings\main\ambient\node\node.d.ts`

I searched around a little but didn't find much
Is this a regression?

data.title: VS Code sends inconsistent Source object in setBreakpointsRequest
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.4

It is not possible to clear or disable breakpoints in inlined source. The reason for this is that a different Source object is passed to setBreakpointsRequest when clearing or disabling the breakpoint.
- set a breakpoint in inlined source
- restart debug session and inspect Source object passed to setBreakpointsRequest:
  ![2016-04-05 16-31-20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14285625/91c6a17c-fb4c-11e5-9b5f-141b19e4625f.png)
  as you can see the Source object has all the information to set the breakpoint in the inlined source
- delete (or disable) the breakpoint and again inspect Source object passed to setBreakpointsRequest:
  ![2016-04-05 16-32-25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14285701/d27694de-fb4c-11e5-910a-ac1662e46047.png)
  
  here the Source no longer has the adapterData which makes it impossible to correctly disable the breakpoint in node 

VS Code must always send the same Source object to setBreakpointsRequest.

data.title: Click to symbol does not jump to file but to the import (JSX/JS).
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 0.10.14-insider (0.10.14-insider)
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Cmd+Click on a Component in JSX (also JS).
2. VSCode jumps to the import and not the file itself.

Expected:
VSCode should just jump to the file referenced in the import as its smart enough to know the specific import.

data.title: No path autocompletion of ES6 modules.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 0.10.14-insider (0.10.14-insider)
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Using ES6 within foo.js try and use autocompletion to insert bar.js
2. "No suggestions"

I don't think this is a bug - rather a feature that does not exist, considering the nature and shape of modern JS, IMHO this should be standard - WebStorm for instance has this and Atom has many plugins that do this - if this is the role of an extension then fair enough - I'll look into writing one, just feel this should be part of the editor core.

data.title: Support snippet variables
data.body:
The [documentation on snippets](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/customization/userdefinedsnippets) says: 

> The snippet syntax follows the TextMate snippet syntax with the exception of 'regular expression replacements', 'interpolated shell code' and 'transformations', which are not supported.

Which implicitly says that VSCode does support variables.

The [TextMate documentation on snippet variables](https://manual.macromates.com/en/snippets#variables) says:

> You can insert the value of a variable by prefixing the name of the variable with $. All the normal dynamic variables are supported, the most useful probably being TM_SELECTED_TEXT. 

Though it does not work, nor does vscode seem to provide an alternative.

---
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Fedora 23

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create user snippet using variable TM_SELECTED_TEXT
2. Use snippet
   -> Does not insert the selected text in place of $TM_SELECTED_TEXT

data.title: Typing fast
data.body:
I type fast. Sometimes, I type very, very fast.

Every now and then, the editor seems to lose a keystroke - does this bother anybody else?

It seems to happen more frequently when using shortcut key combos - for example, I might CTRL+X to cut a line, move the cursor one line up or down, and then CTRL+V to paste. Frequently, one of those three operations simply don't happen.

This is not generally a problem for me in other editors - I don't have this experience in Php Storm or Notepad++ for example.

I wonder if this has something to do with the way you're processing the keyboard events.

I haven't looked at the code, but I wonder - is the stream of keyboard events processed as a single stream? Or are some of the keyboard operations processed by different event listeners? If so, that might be the problem, since this is doesn't (necessarily) give you any direct influence over the order in which the browser dispatches listeners, and/or related events, e.g. key up/down/press.

It's not a huge problem, but it's annoying enough that I wanted to report it - I feel like the editor is training me to type slower, which is annoying, when I switch to other editors that don't have problems keeping up with my typing...

data.title: Test: Support skipping code when stepping
data.body:
for #4798:
- [x] Windows @v-pavanp 
- [x] OS X @alexandrudima 
- [x] Linux @joaomoreno 

We added experimental support for automatically skipping 'uninteresting code' when stepping through code in the debugger. 'Uninteresting code' is code that is generated by a transpiling process but is not covered by a source map so it does not map back to the original source. Typically this code gets into your way when stepping through code in the debugger because it makes the debugger switch between the original source code and generated code that you are not really interested in.

This experimental feature automatically steps through code not covered by a source map until it has reached a location that is covered by a source map again. To enable the feature just add the attribute `smartStep` with a value of `true` to your launch configuration.

Here is a sample project: [async-sample.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/206813/async-sample.zip)
- unzip and open in VS Code
- npm install
- npm run-script compile

Verify that:
- stepping through code stays in the source and does not jump into the generated code (you can see the skipped steps in the debug console).
- stepping still makes sense and you can follow what's going on

data.title: Support for dynamically generated JavaScript and source maps
data.body:
A recent update to SystemJS has broken this feature. I've disabled it for this milestone.

for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4492:
- [ ] Windows
- [ ] OS X
- [ ] Linux

VS Code got experimental support for dynamically generated JavaScript and source maps produced by the universal dynamic module loader [SystemJS](https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs). To support this the node debug extension listens for the "afterCompile" event of the node runtime and triggers a reload of the breakpoints if it detects a dynamically generated JavaScript with an inlined source map.

Please note: since the node runtime does not stop after the generated (transpiled) JavaScript has been compiled, registering breakpoints in the startup phase of the loaded JavaScript might come too late for actually hitting the breakpoints. Registration of breakpoints in code that is executed later works fine.

The snippet that triggered this feature request can be found in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4492.

I will add a better snippet for testing here.

data.title: String truncation limit lifted to 10000
data.body:
- [x] Windows @jrieken 
- [x] OS X @kieferrm 
- [x] Linux @vsccarl 

The node v8 debugger protocol truncates strings automatically to a (non configurable) 80 characters and appends a '...  (length: 123)'.
Node debug tries to extend this rather small limit to 10000 by retrieving the string contents for long strings through 'evaluate'.

Verify that:
- strings in the debugger are only truncated if they are longer than 10000.
- the UI (hovers, variables view, repl) shows long strings correctly.

data.title: Support inspecting large data structures on 4.x and 5.x versions of node.js
data.body:
test item for Microsoft/vscode-node-debug#11:
- [x] Windows - @jrieken 
- [x] OS X - @kieferrm 
- [x] Linux - @vsccarl 

Inspecting large data structures results in slowness (unresponsiveness) issues in node.js because the v8 debugger protocol does not provide a way to access large data structures in chunks. Always the full thing travels over the wire. A particular nasty issue is that local variables are included in the stack frame object "for free" even if nobody requested them. A consequence is that stepping through code with large arrays or buffers in local variables or parameters results in slowness and timeouts.

In node 0.12.x VS Code started to dynamically inject code into the node runtime to improve the v8 debugging protocol but this stopped working after the io.js/node.js reunion for 2.x and 3.x versions. After fix https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/4328 code injection started to work again in node.js 4.3.1 in the LTS stream. For the 5.x stable stream the code injection has to use a slightly different approach that started to work in node 5.6.

Verify for node.js >= 4.3.1 and node.js >= 5.6 that:
- you can inspect large (~ 100000) arrays and buffers without node.js becoming unresponsive

Please note: this feature is not about objects with many properties. Objects with many properties will be addressed in Microsoft/vscode-node-debug#18.

data.title: Data inspection support for ES6 Sets, Maps, and Generators
data.body:
test item for Microsoft/vscode-node-debug#51 and Microsoft/vscode-node-debug#41:
- [x] Windows - @bpasero 
- [x] OS X - @seanmcbreen 
- [x] Linux - @aeschli

VS Code node debugging no longer shows ES6 Sets, Maps, and Generators as undefined or empty objects.

Map:
![map](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14277680/977b973a-fb24-11e5-8232-9c17280a6eeb.png)

Set:
![set](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14277574/08a30700-fb24-11e5-94c6-0bad29ec6896.png)

Generator:
![generator](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/14277448/7156cd00-fb23-11e5-8a63-4548543906a9.png)

Verify that:
- Maps and Sets show their contents in an array like way. Each slot has a sequence number because Maps and Sets preserve insertion order.
- Large Maps and Sets are fast and show their contents in chunks
- Generators show the state of the generator (e.g. 'suspended' or 'closed').

data.title: (C#) Custom classes are recognized by intellisense, but not syntax highlighted
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4 (El Capitan)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Visual Studio Code in a C# project.
2. Create a new class, i.e: MyClass in a file MyClass.cs
3. Go to a different file. Add a MyClass as a member variable

You'll notice that MyClass is not highlighted in the same way that "bool", or "float" might be.

![nocustomclasshighlight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/486972/14276752/f3c889a6-fb17-11e5-97fe-8f3e91c648fc.png)

data.title: How to extend javascript code completion and other features
API: commands.registerTextEditorCommand should support custom args
data.body: As registerCommand does registerTextEditorCommand should support passing in custom arguments.

data.title: API: Diagnostic objects should preserve custom properties
data.body: Since Diagnostic object flow back to the extension host in code action requests custom properties on these object should be preserved as for CompletionItem.
